number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23
												There are a number of different taglines that could better describe the Tomb Raider reboot. How about Lara Croft Causes Everything Wrong with This World or Lara Falls Down and Dies a Lot or even Optional Tomb Raider, where the latter is what I feel would be more appropriate as it was a bit unexpected that raiding tombs would take a back-seat to the rest of the game.The graphical fidelity of Tomb Raider is top notch at maximum settings, particular attention has been paid to the explosions and set pieces. The story is well paced but the secondary and tertiary characters are forgettable and don't really add much to the story other than to cheaply create internal conflict within Lara as she chooses to protect these dependants rather than continue with her main objective. The cinematography is especially fantastic throughout the exciting action sequences. The death scenes are amazing and hilarious, which is nice, since I happened to die an unnecessary amount of times. Being stuck with the same old stock death animations would quickly become annoying but these "tailor made" ones, based on the environment and method of demise, never outgrew their stay. The destruction of the island over the course of the game, as well as when Lara is scaling structures within its zones, is so very cool. Using the bonfires as a vessel for checkpoints and fast travel is very convenient and immersive.I feel that Tomb Raider could be streamlined and made more fun if it weren't for the insane amount of collectables and the occasional endless waves of enemies. I wouldn't at all mind a pure exploration focused version of Tomb Raider with an emphasis on solving puzzles and finding secrets. Regarding enemies, they can be overwhelming and overpowered. They have no determined spawn points during waves, meaning they can spawn right behind Lara when I'm returning from a dead end or jumping from a high perch which is just nonsensical.The RPG elements didn't really fit the tone of the game. I don't see why new abilities and upgrades can't unlock through story progression, as many of the necessary ones did, rather than having to uncover weapon pieces, loot enemies, and salvage gear throughout the environment. How does it make sense, as a role-playing game, to have this innocent, young girl turn into a killing machine with an extensive knowledge to build advanced weaponry from spare parts?There are some odd decisions made in regards to the controls on mouse and keyboard. Lara will often fling into an unintended direction. For instance, I'll press forward and jump, to scale the side of a structure, but Lara will fling herself completely sideways into the abyss and die. It's really hard to predict what will happen when the game seems to be playing against me with every action. It's also clumsy how the controls are selective as to what surface Lara can cling to but yet in cutscenes she can grasp onto anything nearby in order to save her life. My suspension of disbelief has been eliminated so many times during this game.The camera shake is just gross, it's as if Tomb Raider is another title in the series of Jason Bourne films. The bobbing motion during any movement is too much. I like to play with subtitles active and found that the subtitles themselves would often obscure the weapon and ammo interface, meaning I couldn't see if i had my silenced pistol selected during any dialogue taking place.Quick Time Events (QTEs) are lazy and an uninspired way to progress the story or eliminate an enemy. It also doesn't help that they're been implemented sloppily in regards to keyboard and mouse, where the interface makes it difficult to differentiate the E and F keys when time is of the essence. There is far too much reliance placed on QTEs during general gameplay, especially when a significant portion of the action is taken out of my hands. I don't really understand the point of the QTEs when they're mixed in with cutscenes, as it can become hard to distinguish when I'm required to take control of Lara and when the game takes control from me. Not to mention that many of these segments are so prominently the cause of many of my deaths.Half of the game, with regards to its location and lore, is spent working up these mythological Japanese warriors and brutes, introduced as some unstoppable killing machines, only for the first confrontation of the giant "Oni" to end with it being swept up off a bridge with a strong gust of wind. There's no battle, there aren't even any QTEs, it's simply defeated within a cutscene. The later culminating battle against another "Oni" isn't much better, it's a basic 3x3 Nintendo-styled boss battle: three sets of hitting its weak spot three times. And then the final boss is disposed of just as fast as any other obstacle-based QTE. How unsatisfying.In a strange turn of events there are no story related achievements. It's not a big issue but it is odd that a large amount of them are dedicated to the multiplayer and item collection side of things. It's almost as though that's where the game's priorities lie; not in telling a great story but in emphasising its lore and encouraging the player to spend countless hours backtracking and completing the game's challenges, I'm honestly surprised that Ubisoft didn't have anything to do with the development of Tomb Raider. I also don't see any value in testing the multiplayer mode so long after release.While writing this huge wall of text I've begun to wonder if I'm being to harsh on this reboot but then these little frustrations flare up into big frustrations yet again and I'm reminded that, no, I'm not too harsh... it's that Tomb Raider is an average-at-best game with an average-at-best storyline filled with predictable tropes, soulless characters, and a tedious collect-a-thon to artificially extend its playtime.I'm a bit torn for what rating I should give Tomb Raider. It plays like a good game but sometimes it plays like a completely mediocre game. I've decided to rate it positively but damn if I don't hold some grievances. If I could tighten up the controls, remove the RPG elements, and tone down the amount of collectables then I think I'd be pretty well satisfied.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												Story of how the legend was born? Sounds promising, huh? In large part, this anticipation turns out to be true.When reading this review, note I didn't play any other Tomb Raider games before this one. I might now though, inspired by this prelude.Game begins with the very green heroine Lara Croft shipwrecking on a mysterious island with her friends. At first she's helpless, with no weapons nor other equipment to get by. Combined with the circumstance that almost everyone is out to get her, this brings about a unique feeling of vulnerability that diminishes as she grows to become an effortless killing machine.First thing that I noticed was the near-photorealistic graphics. Awe-inspiring, I spent some moments just looking at the scenery and studying the nature and architecture, though this was hard because I was also constantly distracted by feeling danger all around myself. The atmosphere was very well done. You could even experience it in 3D with the right hardware, but unfortunately I don't possess that and couldn't try it.By gameplay, Tomb Raider is a combination of third-person shooter and 3D platformer with minor RPG elements. Then again you can take most enemies out by sneak attacks if you prefer that. You have to deal with different quick-time events from time to time both in-combat and in the more traditional way during scripted events within story. That's actually one of my few complaints: it's sometimes difficult to deduce which keys you are supposed to press during these events, as apparently the key tip disappears under the screen. Fortunately this matters less later when you learn to identify between the events.Edit: Oh, I totally forgot. One thing that bugged me for the whole game. There are ammo literally everywhere! You have to actually be shooting like crazy to run out of ammo.Another minor inconvenience is that one of Lara's many skills is climbing. This is cool. However, she can be stiff and stubborn at times and decide to jump into the direction she was going before instead of jumping up during climb unless you take a moment to calm her down for the maneuver. This led me to many an untimely awkward death, though number of which reduced when I got used to the controls.Single player story is engaging. You get to meet Lara's friends, read (there are notebooks scattered around) about their dreams and doubts and then hope to save them all to get safely back home. Story can be ruthless and sad at times. Along with the story, Lara gets to exercise her archeologist training to study the various artefacts and scriptures found around the island (each provided with an insight from Lara). For the completionist, there are also a number of challenges (basically "find hidden stuff" missions) and puzzle-like optional tombs to complete. These are also useful sources of experience points and salvage (used to upgrade weapons).Unfortunately, for the said completionist, about half the Steam achievements are granted by multiplayer. MP is, at the time of writing, quite dead, i.e. there are no active, permanent lists of servers. However, you can find a player community at Tomb Raider Multiplayer Madness who regularly play (as of 18th Aug 2014) or asking on the forum.While I've heard MP is awesome, I've not actually tried it yet. However, I can recommend Tomb Raider for its single player story alone. On Hard difficulty (that I found to be okay if not challenging) it took me over 20 hours to complete 100%. The present price of 20 € is about half the original price and it's good, but you could probably get it for 10 € or less during sales if you wanted to and the lack of MP kind of justifies that too.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2015
												This is a really good game, better than i remember it, i had the original game on pc back in the day, and the 4th one on Dreamcast and i could never finish them.... not through lack of trying but the jumping had to be so precise it would drive you mad, and it gets really tricky later on. In the 4th one i got stuck at some puzzle where you had to move round really large chess pieces in a particular order and i could never figure out how to position them to open the right gate.They fixed all the issues the old games had with the jumping, and now it gives you room if you mess up a jump slightly you will still grab onto the ledge and not fall to your death over and over. They also fixed the labyrinthine puzzles by  eliminating them altogether,That's kinda the joke actually, all the tombs you can raid in this are both optional, tiny and simple as f*ck, too simple maybe. If you were into Tomb Raider for the puzzles i could see you not liking this game too much.I thought this game struck the right balance between gunplay and exploration, which a lot of game don't get right, but the gunplay and the bow and arrow play? are really satisfying to use on people, you can even use the bow later on once you get the rope upgrade for it to pull enemies off a cliff edge and watch them fall to their deaths.Lara Croft also seems approachable in this, and has a personality of a real person, i'm not sure how much they changed of her story in this reboot, you don't really know if she is still rich and has a mansion. The only thing they messed up is her character arc of becoming a "survivor" replace survivor with killer, it's way more apt. Once she kills the first guy Lara becomes Jane Rambo, there's even achievements for killing 70 people with the assault rifle and 40 people with the shotgun, that aint surviving that's a f*cking massacre son! i'm not complaining about the action, i enjoyed killing all those people, but there's a real disconnect between the story and the gameplay.Anyway play this game if you haven't already, even if you were never a fan of Tomb Raider.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
												I really wish that I could reccommend this game. The gameplay is fun and challenging, but not too difficult to be fun, the graphics are spectacular, and we finally have a good origins game for Laura Croft. However, the coding was intended for a console, and parts of the game have not made a smooth transition to the computer. In several different areas of the campaign, you are required to push a particular button at a particular time, however, it does not register when pushed. This frequently causes an automatic failure and a reloading of the game to the latest checkpoint. I enjoyed playing the game until I got to a point where you are required to push several different buttons in a particular sequence, and the computer simply won't acknowledge that the appropriate button has been pressed, leading to an inability to continue to progress through the campaign.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												Being my first Tomb Raider game, I won't deny that I was quite surprised. Crystal Dynamics did a stellar job in creating Tomb Raider's atmosphere, a cinematic beauty that actually manages to transfer the excitement of discovering a lost civilization into the hearts of the player. The puzzles are fun, some aspects of combat entertaining, and the collectibles are one of the few that I actually bothered to gather.That being said, the game does come with it's flaws. Overabusing quick-time events is, without a doubt, the largest problem as it constantly snatches control away to create something more similar to a movie than a game. There is too much emphasis on combat, whereas the puzzles, which ought to be the focus, are more or less shoved to the corner as optional tasks (Its called "TOMB" Raider for god's sake). Character development isn't that great. While most characters get at least one scene in the spotlight, they never get enough screen time for the player to fully understand them (Ahem* Sam). Finally the game is short, with a storyline that lasts around 15 to 16 hours. Nevertheless, a solid game that should definitely be considered for purchase.  8/10

content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
												I avoided this game when it first came out thinking my almost 6 years old PC (Nvidia 285GTX/Inte lQuad Core Q9300) can't handle it. In the end I've given up the temptation and decided to give it a try and it definitely worth it.The game is well optimized and incredibly fluid (managed to play it on high settings with a constant 35FPS). The graphics are good and the world is well done and same goes for the sound and voice acting.As for the gameplay I can only say that Tomb Raider = Assassin's Creed + Far Cry 3 + Lara Croft.At a smaller scale, of course.It has a cool Far Cry 3 atmosphere and the skill/level up system as well as the weapons upgrade/mod system are similar but not that complex. The platforming is very similar to the one in AC series and that's definitely not a bad thing, What's really cool about this game is that Lara is now a more human now, not overconfident and expressionless like it seamed in the old games. Oh, and she definitely gives you a better view of the...game than Altair or Ezio. From any angle. :D

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												Not having played any of the previous games from the 'Tomb Raider' franchise, I must say this 'reboot' of the famous series did not disappoint and I will definitely be  getting the previous titles in the franchise. This particular Tomb Raider game has our inexperienced heroine along with her whole team of explorers venturing on a ship christened 'The Endurance' when suddenly they are thrown into a scenario where they are shipwrecked on an Island in the Dragon's Triangle called Yamati. On this island survival is the key and this is where we witness Lara Croft's climb from innocent bystander to Lethal Survivalist.So for a newcomer like myself, this reboot series could not have been a better starting point for my introduction into this fantastic franchise. I do however have two questions circulating round in my mind. Question one: why have I only now started taking an interest into one of the most iconic games of all time? Question two: When's the sequel (fingers crossed there will be one) coming out? Come on Square-Enix, Chop-chop.As well as the buxom beaut herself, there is a whole array of intriguing and memorable characters within the plot. There are some you'll love, some you'll despise and some who will get you thinking "Geez when are you going to die"? All these characters have their own motives and are not just throw aways, you'll definitely be finding yourself connecting with these characters for good or for worse. Personally for me there is one character who stood out amongst the rest and that is Conrad Roth, Captain of the Endurance. For some bizarre reason he reminds me of Merle Dixon from AMC's 'The Walking Dead' (Judge it for yourself) and for this reason I soon forgot his actual name and just referred to him as Merle. I'm not saying it’s a bad thing; it's just a personal observation.Onto the gameplay itself which is very compelling and smoothly done. The combat system is extremely satisfying and you'll probably find yourself using the game's signature weapon, the bow to exterminate the enemies encountered within the game, more than anything else. There's nothing more appeasing then bagging a headshot with the bow. The plot is guaranteed to keep you fixed and compelled from start to end, hooked, lined and sinker. The game is free foam which surprised me, as I was expecting linear levels where you could not return too, but Tomb Raider features an open world that you can revisit time and time again, especially to ensure you gather all the collectibles. One of the games mechanics that caught me off guard was the use of 'quick time events'. This particular experience is going to make it hard for me to forget when I reacted slowly to an unexpected occurrence, which lead to me being smushed by a tumbling boulder. Which leads straight into another one of my observations which is how graphic and brutal the deaths can be if you time a certain action wrongly or are just foolish (like me). Tomb Raider definitely has no mercy and when you die once you know not to let it happen again and you ENSURE that you are paying the utmost attention 24/7. Thanks Square-Enix for teaching me to pay attention, you've done a better job then all my Primary and Secondary school teachers combined, for that I salute you. I also wasn't expecting all the jump scares that featured in the game, I'm telling you this so you don't have to go through what I did......which was several pairs of boxers.And finally the best till last the voluptuous vixen herself, Miss Lara Croft (Can I get a Whoop-Whoop?) Square-Enix has done an outstanding job on making Young Lara look like an actual woman and not a sorta woman-thing that has two traffic cones for breasts. This Lara we have been blessed with is definitely a keeper. Everything from her looks to her voice actress, a big shout out to Camilla Luddington on giving us a performance that is so spectacular that she should get an award or something.(Take a hint, all you award givers out there) This is really the kind of voice you expect from England's finest Archaeologist. I also bet a mountain of money that some if not all male gamers will be constantly be stopping in their tracks and tilting their cameras positioning to get those oh so satisfying angles. (Don't be embarrassed, we've all done it, am I right?)I definitely without a shadow of a doubt rate Tomb Raider as one of my favourite games of 2013 and possibly even of all time. All who have read this lengthy review should definitely do it the honour and give it a look see. One last thing, the best piece of music to have on repeat whilst playing Tomb Raider is Jimi Hendrix's Foxy Lady, trust me it just seems so fitting

content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												I say I can develop an very overall opinion. I have played through the campaign at least 3 times and I am level 60 3rd prestige in multiplayer. I have completed the campaign at 100% and play the multiplayer at least once a day with other very good players. The campaign is amazing, storyline is solid, the graphics even more so, but the feelings that it can stir are the best. [Won't spoil anything ;) ] The multiplayer is also very fun. Some might say it is dead, but it is not however. There a couple groups out there with hundreds of members, and a lot of them are active on the game. I used to hate this multiplayer at first. But when you actually get into it and learn how to play properly, it is really fun. Its even more rewarding when you learn tricks on how to play better. I have many friends that are on reguraly that I hop in with. If you are ne to the multplayer, do not be discouraged find some similar levels and play with them. :D I used to be level 30 something with no skill, now I'm one of the better players with even some rumors that I'm a cheater going around lol. My overall rating of the game is a 9/10. Campaign was brilliant, the server side of the multilayer could use some work as well as the leveling system. Otherwise I had and am having fun with this game everyday.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
												I really wish that I could reccommend this game. The gameplay is fun and challenging, but not too difficult to be fun, the graphics are spectacular, and we finally have a good origins game for Laura Croft. However, the coding was intended for a console, and parts of the game have not made a smooth transition to the computer. In several different areas of the campaign, you are required to push a particular button at a particular time, however, it does not register when pushed. This frequently causes an automatic failure and a reloading of the game to the latest checkpoint. I enjoyed playing the game until I got to a point where you are required to push several different buttons in a particular sequence, and the computer simply won't acknowledge that the appropriate button has been pressed, leading to an inability to continue to progress through the campaign.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												Great graphics, still holds up 2 and half years later. However, I think that's the only real highlight of this game. I'm a fan of linear singleplayer games, like Half-Life, Wolfenstein the New Order, and Max Payne, but the reason I didn't like this game that much is because it felt like the game was holding my hand through the entire experience. There really isn't much interactivity, and there are way too many quick time events. I liked the stealth parts of the game, but the combat just isn't very good; the weapons don't handle very well. It feels like they tried mashing realistic weapon combat with a video game style, and it just doesn't work. I don't recommend this game at full price, but pick it up on sale. It's not bad, it's just mediocre.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
												+++ :+ Lara Croft - Sadly I've never played previous TR games. But any gamer wud recognize the most popular female video game character of all time in an instant. This reboot gives her a much needed Origin story & Camilla Luddington does an excellent job of bringing a highly likable protagonist to life. + Graphics are Incredible - this is High settings on 768p & FB reduces Pic quality - so u can Imagine how better it cud look! + Story - Perfect blend of Adventure & Myth. Lara's origin story is dark and gritty yet fun at the same time. The character development shown throughout is believable. + Gameplay - Controls are fine, Great Auto-Cover system, Exploring the island for Tombs & Rewards is satisfying which acts as the catalyst for the well thought out Progression system, Enemy AI is good, basically just traversing the area with custom ziplines and killing bad guys with Lara's trademark Bow is fun! - - - :- Multiplayer - Pretty generic with Few maps and modes. This game doesnt even need MP in the first place. - Charted Territory - This game certainly reminds me of Uncharted in terms of almost everything. There's not a lot of original content in this. But that's not necessarily a bad thing. = = = :Verdict : 9/10

												I like the game. I really do.Despite:The idiotic QTEs Seriously, that mechanic always was and still is just a lazy, lazy development.The huge number of walk by wire scenes that could have been plain old cutscenes.The enournomous number of cutscenes that are absolutely not needed.I never have been a fan of Tomb raider games, but this one is fun.However what is a huge dealbreaker for me and is the reason why I do not recommend this game is headbobbing. WTF is with that. Yes I do know that in real life there is such a thing. But 1) In real life we don't notice it. 2) it's a game not real life, stop trying to make everything realistic. You always fail. And always will fail at that.At least give us an option to turn it off.Dear Square Enix I really enjoy your games and you are one of only two triple A publilshers whose games I still buy. Please stop with lazy development, poor PC ports and idiotic "features", such as fake realism. Head bobbing isn't realistic. However Lara dying long before she got anywhere past the beach campfire would have been.

content:
Posted: March 28
												Tough to decide whether to recommend or not. Unfortunately, Steam's (bad) system means I gotta thumbs down.Positives:Good graphics & performance (on Linux, too).Fairly good story.Mostly bug-free.Negatives:No real puzzles. The core game levels never even try, while the side rooms have puzzles which feel more like tutorials. Practically no thinking required.Extremely easy - even on hardest. If you get a bit hurt just crouch behind something. Just headshot everything - they make it easy by taking ages to shoot.You can't fall off ledges... It's like a car game that won't let you crash.The AI are very poor. Sometimes they just stand there when they have a totally unobstructed shot.Lots of quicktime events (mindless parts where you just have to push keys/controller buttons when they tell you). If I wanted a clicker I'd buy one.Checkpoints. No real saves. (I know this is common nowdays, but can someone please explain why we're going backwards on this? (De)serializing a list of entities isn't that hard).Annoying shared key-bindings. [Use] = [Ignite torch].A lot of those are basically negatives caused by console-ification - without then choosing to adapt the PC version for PC play-style (harder, more keys and complex controls, no hand-holding, real saves).But if you're after a pretty, mindless shooter with a bit of a story, it's probably a great buy.(EDIT: Just improved formatting)

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2013
												Tomb Raider is a game where you find yourself as an adventurer named Laura Croft, looking for a mysterious Japanese legend which is about the "Sun Queen". This game has beautiful graphics, really detailed backrounds, objects and much more. It's also very hard but fair combat (unless you play on the lower difficulties) as you have limited ammo and have to lote your enemies often to find "Salvege" that you can use to upgrade your weapons with. The story and the lores/objects you find in the world are often worth while looking in too as they can hold useful information as well as sometimes give you some XP! The enemy AI is very realistic (for being maniacs) those with guns don't just rush up on you but always take cover and makes comments about what they are doing and what you are doing. Even those with melee weapons don't always recklessly rush you, they often stick from cover to cover until they are so close that they can rush you. One complaint about them tough, when you find yourself in a situation of few covers and they have molotoves (did I spell that right?) they constantly never run out of them so you have only a few moments where you can shoot them. It's also fun and rewarding to hunt animals in the wilds, as the map is pretty much an open world, but the animals sometimes are pretty stupid but I won't complain about that. Sometimes you also find Tombs that are totally free to explore if you want, in the begining they are pretty easy but as it goes on they become very hard. They give you a lot of salvege as a reward! Now I have not played the entire game but I have tried the multiplayer and let's just say that it doesn't bring out the strong side of this game! But it hardly brings down the experience of the single player as you will spen hours there of hunting, sneaking, exploring, looting, upgrading, and dying horrible deaths in this game! A 9/10 from me!

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												I have completed this game on the PlayStation 3.It's pretty nice, graphic-wise it's beautiful, the game mechanics are a little rusty but not bad at all. The beginning is a little rough, but it does a great job of serving you the situation and what everyone wanted to do before♥♥♥♥♥♥hit the fan. It's basically Uncharted subbed with a heroine and a different setting (Japan). There's not a lot of variety when it comes to weapons, just 4 or 5 but I mostly just use the bow and arrow anyways so I'm not too disappointed. It touches the free roam genre a little bit because it allows you branch off of the story line and go into optional tombs that are not part of the story line but are lore-friendly. You are able to go back to previously played areas and use new equipment you get as you further progress and explore new areas or get around faster. It's pretty brutal, lots of blood, I was being dragged down a river by this strong current, I strayed to close to the riverbank and this pole impaled my face from the bottom of my throat out through the top of my head. However, it repeated the same animation pretty much at every spot on the river I tried to do it, so it is a bit repetitive in that aspect but nonetheless it's pretty gruesome. It is balanced between caves/outside, I never got too bored or ever wanted to hurry up and finish a level just so I could get it over with. I am a little disappointed with how saturated the game is with enemy humans, I feel like it's too much like a third person shooter rather than a survival game. There are A LOT of collectibles like journals or relics that tell history (mostly legend) and that make the game feel more like a tomb raider game. The level up system is XP based and when you rank up you pick a perk (bigger bandolier for ammo or get more salvage from animals, etc.) Salvage is all the bits and pieces you pick up from crates and dead animals that you are able to use to upgrade your weapons. Upgrades add a good feel and customization to the game because whatever you upgrade, it stays on the actual model itself, so if you buy a part that makes your pistol more accurate it changes the skin of the pistol and not just keeps it the same looking piece of trash. You can find more pieces of upgrade by exploring or killing large targets. Overall it is a pretty decent game.

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												One of the most overrated games I have stumbled upon. Don't get me wrong. Tomb Raider is not a bad game, it's just not a good game and according to how it has been received it's supposed to be an excellent one. TR loans a lot from Arkhan Batmans but in generally just does those same things worse. Most of the combats are pre-written and you just start from an awkward position surrounded by enemies. This works well in Max Payne but not in TR. The QTEs are awful. Almost always they are instant kills and the game does a poor job at communicating what it wants the player to do and sometimes you don't even know how to control your character. The worst part about the QTEs is that many otherwise nice cinematic scenes are abruptly distracted by a sudden QTE which kills you and you have to start from the beginning. I often felt "Fine! I won't try to enjoy this cinematic scene which is trying to show me nice action with interesting environment. Instead I'll play the most boring game ever: Press E when a red circled E is shown on the screen." I was also put off by the fact that the game throws out logic, realism and physics and if you try to apply any of these you can end up having unnecessary difficulties or are just unable to finish a puzzle. Instead you're supposed to try to figure out what the game wants you to do and just do that.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												Casuals strike hard in this is one. Playing at hardest difficultly, shooting elements are♥♥♥♥♥♥easy, the pistol, your starter, easily decimates enemies through the whole game. Mind you it requires constant head shots, but enemies often come one by one, and approach slowly enough to aim properly. Gun upgrades are randomized through searching for boxes which is a huge time waster. I searched for hours to find upgrades for guns I don't use. The stealth integrated into this game is an illusion, multiple places that hinted at a stealth option only lead to death when the only exit was impossible to sneak through. Expploration is also a joke, places I had thought were off the beaten path were explored later in the game through the story. Tomb puzzles are♥♥♥♥♥♥easy and require 5mins or less to complete. There are base camps that allow you to return to an earilier area, however it is easy to spot all the "hidden" areas the first time around so these are rarely touched. Laura's breasts aren't big enough in comparison to the pervious. It's like she's been getting breast reductions every game.6/10 - (8/10 for Laura moaning at every wound)

content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												Bought this on a lark for less than $10. I probably would not have finished the game had I rented it. Tomb Raider shows promise, but is ultimately less than the sum of its parts. Crystal Dynamics have relegated Lara Croft to an unforgivingly linear character action game that wears its influences on its tank top. Too much Uncharted, not enough Prince of Persia. The sense of exploration from previous games in the series has all but vanished, replaced with (admittedly capable) gunplay in poorly-designed arenas. The traversal neither feels as good as Uncharted or Enslaved nor offers the flexibility of Assassin's Creed or the Batman Arkham series.This bird may be pretty, but there's not much going on beneath the surface. A handful of collectathons are hardly incentive enough to keep Tomb Raider on my modest SSD. An utterly forgettable experience.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												This game was the biggest dissapointment of the year for me.It is not really a Tomb Raider game (only parts of the very final battle feel anything like previous games in the series), or much of a game at all given how on rails and scripted it all is.  The only challenges are obviously shoe-horned in so that you don't fall asleep.This is a perfect example of a AAA title gone bad, as it's like 4 teams were each trying to copy as many features from as many other games as they each could without ever coordinating with any other team to make sure the features they added make any sense.  Then they pulled a generic story out of their asses, dressed it up kinda pretty (some levels look ok on PC, but there are games that are 5 years old that look better).I'd say it's an alright game for those that wanna watch a movie, but the story is just awful (none of the characters are played out very well, and half the script was torn straight from some Hollywood B-Flick) and there are "quick-time" events constantly in a game where half the time you don't actually move on your own (there's no prompt letting you know when you do or do not have control, so half the game you think you're doing something but if you put the controller down the game just keeps playing itself for a while until you die from missing a button press event or what-have-you).I don't really have anything nice to say about this game.  I payed $5 for it, and feel like that was a bit much.  I'm not sure what the developers were trying for, but they should definitely be embarassed by their involvement in the production of such a hyped-up pile of♥♥♥♥♥♥as Tomb Raider was.  I really hope this new Lara Croft universe dies with this game and they bring back the old story-lines and mechanics for the next game, cause this game just about killed the franchise for me.As for games to pick up instead, just about anything else would feel like less of a waste than this game.

												Mash E to delete from hard drive.On a more serious note, this game has an OK story and a good presentation, interesting art style and beautiful graphics. What it lacks is interesting and engaging gameplay. The parts without enemy encounters are well executed and fun, climbing and salvaging and whatnot, but in fights, there is so very little gameplay besides QTEs. It felt like about a third of the game was me playing, another third was cutscenes (walk through that narrow gap in some debris? Cutscene! Walk back through that gap? CUTSCENE!) and the last part was, you guessed it, QTEs. In conclusion, if you like to play games yourself instead of having the game play for you, this is not for you. It made me think of a Telltale title without the dialogues.Oh, and the replayability is very limited due to the linear nature of the game. The only incentive would be to get 100% of the collectibles.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2016
												For being called "Tomb Raider", there isn't really that much tomb raiding. You're spending most of your time killing mooks. That good and all, the combat is great, but I was really hoping for (and expecting) more dungeon crawling action. And yes there are a few tombs in the game, but they're really nothing more than simple minidungeons. So yeah, combat plays a very large role. Besides that there are some platforming and puzzle sections, but they are extremely easy and there's not much of it. Exploration is also lacking. You are certainly rewarded for your curiosity, with EXP and/or materials. These can be used to upgrade weapons and unlock new abilities. Now they are well executed and certainly very usefull, but since you can also aquire both of these things from killing mooks (even though it's usually much less) it becomes far less exciting when you go out of your way to clear a tomb, just get more of the same you already have. It may be useful, but it kinda feels like a waste of time; which is a shame because you certainly don't clear them for the challenging puzzle you need to solve to get to the end. Zelda this ain't. The collectibles are great though. There's all sorts of collectibles, but the best ones are the artifacts and the diaries. When you collect an artifact you don't just get the 3D model of the item, but also a little bit of information of its original use, which is rather intresting and increases the feeling of being an adventurer. The diaries are of course from other characters, friends and enemies alike; and I like them because they give a little bit of backstory and character development to its writer. These help making the exploration better for sure, but it's just too bad you don't come across them that often.As for the combat? It's excellent. You got many different weapons that you can upgrade in useful ways as mentionned before, it's challenging in the right way, there's stealth sections and it's just very well executed. The graphics are amazing (this is a very pretty game), music is good but nothing spectacular, the story is intresting, voice acting is very good and the controls are nice and tight. Levels are mostly pretty linear but are connected to one another and you can backtrack to any area you visited in case you missed something in the more open sections. The areas you visit are very detailed and pleasing to look at, and create a nice setting, putting you in the same mood als Lara Croft would be. So, the game is not bad. It's very polished and everything works very well; no problems with level design, enemy placement, glitches, game mechanics or anything like that. It's just a shame that there is an overemphasys on combat and very little dungeon crawling. Exploration lacking and the survival element is non-existent; collecting plants or flaying animals just yields more EXP. If you don't mind that you will no doubt love this game. But if you're like me and were hoping for more emphasys on exploration, tomb raiding and puzzle solving, you might not find what you're looking for here.

number of helpful: 10 of 18 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												A Survivor is Born....To sum it all up, this game is INTENSE!!!! Now, I wasn't really a fan of the Tomb Raider franchise until this one..... this one took the series to a whole new level.This is the origin of how Lara Croft became who she is....  This game is not about the making of an action hero but a story of a girl doing everything she must in order to survive. She is faced with challenges along the way as she discovers the secrets of the island....The story of the game is just splendid ^_^ It's  well written and easy to follow, with lots of twists and turns that will keep you on edge.... I can't spoil it so you'll just have to find out for yourself. The character development is also very well executed and so is the superb voice acting.The visuals are beautiful. I can't get enough of how rich the environments are. Every place feels different from the last one and it doesn't feel repetetive. Partner that with the amazing musical score of Jason Graves and you've got a Masterpiece....On towards the gameplay..... smooth movements, no camera issues, auto-crouching when enemies are nearby, aiming is easy and well done and it's so satisfying to perform headshots on enemies :D You also have survival instincts which points out enemies, animals (for hunting), artifacts, and crucial items you need to progress... Difficulty is just about right. On easy, Lara is pretty much indestructible :/ so you need not worry about dying all the time XD although you need to be fast during the QTE or she will die a very gruesome death -_-Overall Experience: Wow.... Just wow!!! If it seems like I'm giving out too much praise for this game, it's because it deserves it. You have to experience this for yourself to get what I really mean. It's an action-packed adventure and I highly recommend it ^_^

content:
Posted: September 15, 2016
												This game is a museum of everything I hate about modern video games.Scripted AFButton Mash-y AFQTE AFPerks AFGiant-glowing-quest-marker AFBONUS-HEADSHOT-XP AFRegenerating-health AFGameplay-badass-cutscene-dumbass AFThis-character-you've-known-for-10-minutes-died-please-feel-sad-now AFInterrupt-the-gameplay-to-force-the-camera-to-look-here AFEASY AFSuper-detective-vision-for-no-reason AFOh-no-this-building-is-burning-down!-but-you-can-take-your-time-because-it's-just-scripted-manufactured-urgency AFWeapon-upgrades-are-pointless-because-you-are-constantly-drenched-in-ammo AFBut-rope-arrows-are-still-infinite AFTomb-Raider-game-where-you-don't-raid-a-single-tomb AFBland-third-person-cover-shooter AFLemme-slow-down-time-and-highlight-all-the-bad-guys-for-you AFLemme-slow-down-time-and-auto-aim-at-that-obstacle-for-you AFLook-at-all-these-convenient-explosive-barrels AFCONSOLISED AY EFFOne time, there was a scripted event where Lara climbed a ladder, and afterwards you can't climb back down the ladder.One time, Lara has to balance over a fallen trunk, and the game makes a huge show of how precarious it is even having Lara trip and almost fall halfway across, but you can't actually fall off no matter how wildly you mash buttons.One time, Lara has to climb up this precarious ladder, and things are falling off, and she might lose her grip!!  Just kidding, I don't care because all I'm doing is pressing forward and letting the game play itself.One time, Lara gets impaled on a needle, then falls down a cliff, then gets attacked by wolves, then 10 minutes into this game you've already lost any emotional connection to this character because so much outrageous sh*t has happened to her already that you just don't care anymore.One time, Lara picks up a WWII shotgun and immediately knows how to use it.  Later, she assembles an AK-47 from parts she found.  Still needs to be told how to work a radio though.One time, Lara, equipped with an assault rifle, combat shotgun, and pistol, comes upon a group of unarmed baddies during a cutscene.  She tries to take them on with her bow and gets captured.One time,  Lara, equipped with an assault rifle, combat shotgun, and pistol, does nothing as a baddie kills an innocent dude, then tries to shush her walkie-talkie so he won't notice she's there.  At this point, I had killed about 400 people, give or take.One time, Lara is given a climbing axe, but you can't use it in combat until you unlock the "Use climbing axe in combat" perk.  Until then, she just pushes people.  Once you unlock the "Use climbing axe in combat" perk, you still need to unlock the "Use climbing axe to kill people perk".  Until then, after she melees people with her climbing axe, she kills them with a rock picked up from the ground, but not the climbing axe.  You need to unlock the perk to kill people with the climbing axe after you hit them with the climbing axe.One time, the game was like "Collect 5 bird eggs" and I was like "But why?" and the game said "Because then you get the collect 5 bird eggs achievement".One time, the game was like "Kill a crab" and I was like "But why?" and the game said "Because then you get the kill a crab achievement".One time, I beat this game 100% and none of the achievements unlocked.One time, I realized playing this game felt like a chore, and I never want to do it again.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Recommended, but with some reservations...POSITIVESThe Tomb Raider reboot is visually stunning. I like the exploration aspects and the tomb raiding is especially fun. I was thrilled when the game opened with survivalism and hunting gameplay, but unfortunately it never plays much of a factor. The initial stealth combat and action sequences are exciting.  NEGATIVESTomb raiding is infrequent and short. I was disappointed with the enemy AI. Once you are discovered they gain super-radar and always know your exact location (a major pet peeve of mine). I found the action and combat sequences increasingly ridiculous and overly long. Lara vs. 1000 Mercenaries and the mercenaries don't stand a chance.BOTTOM LINEI liked Tomb Raider initially, but I struggled to finish the game. My rating is 6/10: Good, but not overly memorable or long lasting. If you like long over-the-top action and combat sequences, you might enjoy the entirety of the game. However, if you get bored with ridiculous and long action sequences, you may want to consider passing on Tomb Raider.

												"I hate tombs."    -- Lara Croft To be honest, I have never been a tomb raider fan. I grew up hearing about the game, played one or two of the series, but it never appealed to me... until now. The Lara Croft I knew was this super woman (and super hot ) wielding duel pistols, shooting wolves and climbing ridges. But this game gave me a whole new Lara. She's more like a neighbour girl. She would also be scared, panting, comforting herself "shhhhhhhh"; She would be faschinated by her findings, frustrated when things don't work out, and disgusted when falling into a blood pool. She now feels more humane than an action figure. I absolutely love it. After all, tomb raiding isn't an easy task. The gameplay is smooth and intense. The transition from the cutscenes to gameplay is perfect. and the control is easy to handle. Graphics, well grapphis still looks pretty good even after 3-4 years.  Applause for the collectible settings ! I can upgrade my abilities which makes them easier to find. God knows how much I love collecting things in video games ! It doesn't always have to be a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥does it ? Checkpoints settings are reasonable. I hate going through the same boring climbing over and over again.  The story line is intriguing and clear, yet somewhat lacks the elements of surprises. Feels like they are scraping the bottom of the tomb raider franchise. No judgement, since I seldom play the previous series. It's good that i can also learn some history(don't know if the facts are accurate) via artifacts. I am a simple Chinese girl. I see Chinese jade dagger/fan/bowl I recommend ! :D Too bad that my potatoe computer can't handle the rise of the Tomb raider.  I wanna play it after finishing this one. 10/10 will hate tombs again

content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												Tomb Raider is a mature experience featuring a young, strong woman who - armed with grit, determination, and intelligence - rescues not only her friends but herself as well. Surely there’s a lesson in that for the rest of us.Rebooting Tomb Raider is the best thing that could have happened to the series. The game is full of story-wise emotions and superbly directed action scenes, and it still has a very strong human factor. I'm rarely this positive about a game. Crystal Dynamics took a risk that won't appeal to some orthodox fans, but all in all the developers have succeeded. The most important thing to know is this: the new Tomb Raider is one of the best action-adventure games I have ever played.I TRULY LOVE THIS GAME!              AND I RECOMMEND THIS GAME!

												Surprisingly good fun. The storyline, dialogue and supporting cast are pretty poor, but the concept of making Lara Croft more like an actual human person and less like a pair of murderous, somersaulting boobs was a great move. You'll laugh and flinch at the gruesome and the ludicrous as Lara's day gets progressively more awful. The platforming in this game is smooth, the combat is satisfyingly crunchy. Leveling up and modding weapons is genuinely rewarding. The visuals hold up pretty well for a previous-gen title.  Granted this is mostly an Uncharted game with a a posh, humourless female Nathan Drake, but it's no less fun for all that.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												3rd person action-adventure. Pleasantly surprised by this, I was unsure after my first go but spending a little longer with it has definitely increased my opinion of it.Warning: It's really quite brutal at times and there's a bit of swearing. Definitely not one for the kids..This is essentially the game equivalent of a good blockbuster action movie: Totally ridiculous in numerous ways and relatively shallow but looks the part and is lots of fun despite it's flaws.There are only two elements of the game that I don't like:1) QTEs (Quick Time Events). Not being a console gamer, this is my first experience of them and they seem totally ridiculous and out of place. e.g. A wolf jumps out at you, a message appears on screen saying 'mash left and right'. okay.. do that for a bit, everything goes all slowmo and another message appears saying 'press f to defend'. I'm a second too slow and the wolf mauls me to death. Some of these sequences have 5-6 steps of pressing or mashing different keys and it's all so random, you'll have no idea what is needed until the message appears on screen so you'll almost certainly fail first time and then pass second time once you know the sequence. It's never hard, just pointless and arbitrary. Thankfully the game invariably autosaves (remarkably unobtrusively) just before these moments so it's never a real drag, also QTEs are mercifully not that common.2) Camera control. I often feel like I'm fighting with the game to try and get the camera pointing where I want. As you move forward, the camera is pulled into a position behind you looking forward. If you want to look sideways, up, down or behind while moving then you'll be fighting with it, which can get really irritating.Everything else is good, Lara's movement is nice and smooth, combat is fun, story is decent, exploring an environment and finding how to get to difficult-to-access secret areas is probably my favourite aspect.Overall, I'd certainly recommend giving this a go.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												An absolutely beautiful, riveting game. It only take a minute into the intro video for you to realize you've just loaded up and epic tale. This is far and away my favorite single player game, the story having made it hard to get off to go to work. I just had to know what happened. 10/10. The visuals are stunning (GTX 770m if that helps anyone), and her hair had enough detail to require a special graphics option just for it. 10/10. The audio is perfect, with the sounds of wind, gunshots and even breaking sticks changing depending on how enclosed the environment is, how close or far the action was, and, if I'm not mistaken, even if it was on the other side of a wall or rock. 10/10. Controls are simple and easy to use, with little difficulty understanding even the most intricate of actions. The same goes for the user interface, with nothing but your mini-map displayed most of the time. That's the pros of the game, and while I love this game, I will talk about the downsides. To start, if your looking for online, look somewhere else. The online for this game doesn't exist anymore as of the writing of this review, and didn't when the game had released. It was clunky, slow, and had some glitches that didn't seem right most of the time. I'm an online gamer, GoW3 being my go to for 3rd person action, and I would recommend that to you as well if you want that style. For this and other reasons (can't play Laura till max level >.<) this game receives a 3/10 for online. Now second up is graphics. Let me explain before you blow up about how I already gave graphics a high score. The are amazing, they are. But their level of amazingness can be a bit much at times, for both myself and my computer. When your trotting along and suddenly five men attack you, you have bullets, fire, explosions, arrows, bodies, plants, rain, wind, debris etc. flying around on screen. This puts strain on your computer as with nearly any AAA game. Now add amazing graphics, and set them on high or higher (pun intended) and your computer will freak, tank the fps, and try to cope with the maddening amount of crap on screen. To top the insane flurry of activity, add in a motion blur that's even more realistic than jerking my own head around, and you've got the perfect headache cocktail. Now this doesn't hurt the graphics rating, but it is something to watch out for. If you get this game, mess around with the graphics settings and see what your comp, and you, can handle before you get into a motion storm. All in all, still my favorite game, over any of the Bioshock's, and I have a Big Daddy tattoo. For a final score, Tomb Raider deserves a 9.5/10 without online, and a 9/10 with it (10/10 is reserved for a game I can find no qualms with).

												Ok i have finished it so time to write some words.What to say it is a good game realy not bad it has good graphics and the story and gameplay are not bad.Now some indepth.At he begining it had somekind of survival feel to it (Kill animals and gather plants get supply) but as soon you leave the place you realy dont need it since you get supply from crates and killed enemy.The weapons uh! I mean they are not bad the upgrades are not bad but it kinda feels you realy dont need them. I mean i never upgraded my assault rifle it kinda upgraded its self when i progresed (dont ask me how). The upgrades dont seem like they matter since i was mostly going stealth and using bow and arrow headshot and done the diference in aiming when you buy a upgrade for better aiming is realy superficial. Some armored guys i take out hand to hand.The cover system is realy idiotic. I mean when you cower behind a wall stick to it! Sometimes that stupid girl just gets out of cover and the enemy just spots her witch is kinda anoying.The story is good but you kinda get the feeling ¨The princes is in another castle¨ plus when you see how many times Lara just falls down in  the cutscenes you kinda wonder how did she not break much more bones. That kinda bugs me but oh well. And in adition when you get atacked from enemys and start killing them you kinda start wondering ¨Holy crap how big of a cult is this¨ And to get all the story you need to get realy ALL of the documents. Oh and when Lara kills someone the first time she barfs a litle  the facial expretions are good but after that its like ¨Fu*k it im gonna kill ya all you basterds¨ kinda hoped for more struggle.All in all it is not bad i would realy like to see more of survival elements it would bring kinda more depth in the game. The puzzles is also not bad. Not to hard just right for my taste since this is realy the first Tomb Rider i have EVER played.Anyway it was on sale so i got it for 4 euro it was not a bad deal so for the mony i would say it is a 7/10 game. Recomended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												-Single player review only.-This review is not based on the multiplayer aspect of Tomb Raider 2013."I hate tombs!" -Lara Croft 2013Let me start off by saying I have played Tomb Raider games since I was very yong, back thenthe games were challengeing, exciting, and very rewarding once you figured out the puzzle you were stuck on fortwo days. I felt exactly the opposite feelings playing Tomb Raider 2013. The game was very linier, tombs were easy to figure out and the over all story felt flawed or unthought thrugh.However these are just some blemishes on a rather fun game.First lets give some overview on what the game is about.This is NOT the Lara Croft we know and love,She happens to be a completely new character, also named Lara Croft and was created by Crystal Dynamics and Square Enixfor Tomb Raider 2013, This Croft is green, setting out on her first expedition about the ship Endurance, with the intention of finding the lost kingdom of Yamatai with her best friend Samantha. The expedition ventures into the Dragon's Triangle, east of Japan with the hopes of finding Yamatai. The ship is struck by a violent storm and split in two, leaving the survivors stranded on an isolated island. Lara must now use her survival instincts to find her way back to the crew of the Endurance and find a way off the island.As you venture thrugh the game you come across tombs hidden around the map, exploring these tombs present you with a puzzle, usualy one that you can figure out within seconds of scanning the area, or if that is too easy for you, use your survival insti♥♥♥♥ to really make sure you don't get stuck in the tomb. Clearing the tombs will give you one stat point twords any of the provided stats in the game, such as Brawler, Survivor, and scavenger among others you will unlock later. These skills will allow you to play the game the way you like to play, be it a Call of Duty in your face 1v50 deathmatch or sneaking around taking out your enemies one by one. You can chose to ignore these tombs and just go stright to the end of the game if that is what you wish.The game does a great job of laying out the lore and back story of the Yamata thrugh books and hidden artifacts laying around the map, not force feeding you all the information at once thrugh boring charicter interactions, heck you are rarely in the company of others. I found looking for these lore books one of the best parts of the game, I wanted to know more about this island and the things in it more than exploring tombs. The action presented in every part of the game was amazing, very nice camera angles paired with the stunning visuals of Lara and the enviorment left me actually feeling like I was in danger, I felt like I needed to save my own life and get out of trouble as fast as possible, I could not ask for a better experiance than that.This lara Croft's signature weapon in this game is the bow, and my personal favorite weapon in the game, I rarely used anything else unless given a situation that required a lot of stoping power. however as you progress thrugh the story you are given other weapons such as the pistol and shot gun to help clear obsticals you will encounter, every weapon in the game is uprageable to make them more effective in combat.I played thrugh the game on Hard on my first playthrgh and I really did not find it to be that challenging, however the legeth of the game and finding the stuff around the map more than made up for it. I really recommend this game to anyone looking to lose a few hours of their life to a game, and for the price you really can't beat it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 16, 2014
												This isn't the old Tomb Raider that was filled with puzzles and adventure.  It has some of that, but nothing like the anniversary edition.This is the prequel of Tomb Raider.  It is VERY linear with mostly first-person-shooter gameplay.  You won't get lost in this game easily, since there is constant check-points and beacons.  The graphics are excellent.  For what the game is, without comparison to anniversary, it's quite fun.  You play Lora before she became tough.  You get to watch her go from a fragile and scared girl to a warrior.The combat controls work rather well, I had no trouble with fighting once I got the hang of it.  And there's tons of fighting.  Everything was fairly easy to kill, I think, but not as simple as some games.  I think the stealth system might have wanted some more work, but overall the game seemed rather polished.  Though, I would love to see a tomb raider that didn't have any combat, just rock climbing and puzzles/traps.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												Underrated gem. The graphics, animation, controls, movement, personality, upgrade system, environment, it's all just absolutely amazing. I love this game, and I think I'm going to play it again pretty soon! It's a little on the short side, and that's my only complaint. Even with exploring all the side tombs and collecting all (or most) of the goodies on the map, it still seemed a little short. The production values and overall gameplay experience made up for it. It's also a bit more corridor-like than I might have preferred, but the Tomb Raider series isn't known for being open world.I would say if you can pick this game up for around $25 or less, it's a good deal. It took me about 15-20 hours to beat, but it's good enough for another playthrough. I can't comment on the multiplayer because I'm totally not interested in PvP and that's all the multiplayer is. If it had some kind of co-op, that would be awesome!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												It's funny how Lara is so reluctant in taking a life at the beginning even if the guy is pure evil and the next 3/4 of the game you spend in murdering people Gears of War style. Other than that the game is pretty good with lots of stuff to do and a beautiful island to explore. Story is mediocre but what makes the game stand out is the action mechanics and the way Lara interacts with everything in the world. The survival element is strong at the beginning but after half an hour worth of killing baddies you seem pretty indestructible and able to take anything that dares to cross your path. That is quite inconsistent with the weak and vulnerable potrait they tried to give to Lara. Despite its inconsistencies the game handles amazingly and is a lot of fun. Would definitetly recommend to any action/adventure fun and to all others a buy on a sale.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												An absolutely beautiful, riveting game. It only take a minute into the intro video for you to realize you've just loaded up and epic tale. This is far and away my favorite single player game, the story having made it hard to get off to go to work. I just had to know what happened. 10/10. The visuals are stunning (GTX 770m if that helps anyone), and her hair had enough detail to require a special graphics option just for it. 10/10. The audio is perfect, with the sounds of wind, gunshots and even breaking sticks changing depending on how enclosed the environment is, how close or far the action was, and, if I'm not mistaken, even if it was on the other side of a wall or rock. 10/10. Controls are simple and easy to use, with little difficulty understanding even the most intricate of actions. The same goes for the user interface, with nothing but your mini-map displayed most of the time. That's the pros of the game, and while I love this game, I will talk about the downsides. To start, if your looking for online, look somewhere else. The online for this game doesn't exist anymore as of the writing of this review, and didn't when the game had released. It was clunky, slow, and had some glitches that didn't seem right most of the time. I'm an online gamer, GoW3 being my go to for 3rd person action, and I would recommend that to you as well if you want that style. For this and other reasons (can't play Laura till max level >.<) this game receives a 3/10 for online. Now second up is graphics. Let me explain before you blow up about how I already gave graphics a high score. The are amazing, they are. But their level of amazingness can be a bit much at times, for both myself and my computer. When your trotting along and suddenly five men attack you, you have bullets, fire, explosions, arrows, bodies, plants, rain, wind, debris etc. flying around on screen. This puts strain on your computer as with nearly any AAA game. Now add amazing graphics, and set them on high or higher (pun intended) and your computer will freak, tank the fps, and try to cope with the maddening amount of crap on screen. To top the insane flurry of activity, add in a motion blur that's even more realistic than jerking my own head around, and you've got the perfect headache cocktail. Now this doesn't hurt the graphics rating, but it is something to watch out for. If you get this game, mess around with the graphics settings and see what your comp, and you, can handle before you get into a motion storm. All in all, still my favorite game, over any of the Bioshock's, and I have a Big Daddy tattoo. For a final score, Tomb Raider deserves a 9.5/10 without online, and a 9/10 with it (10/10 is reserved for a game I can find no qualms with).

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												This is the best version of Simon Says I've ever played. Sometimes the little circle will shrink into the other circle and you think you have to press "F" but really you have to press "G" (or was that Mouse-4?). The best part is watching death animations over and over until your get the right combination. No, you can't just kill the wolf, you have to beat the wolf in a game of Simon Says. And when the game tells you to "Mash F" what it really means is "Tap F with a precise frequency - not too fast or slow".Think of this as the spiritual successor to Dragon's Lair.

												Great game, but it felt a bit clunky with my mouse and keyboard. I can not recommend this game to everyone, so try it before you buy it. I did not draw any emotional connections to the characters and I did not feel interested in what would happen next in the main story line. But the game was a lot of fun,  beautiful, and exciting. The combat was excellent for a Tomb Raider game (or for any game for that matter). I think the best part of the game was the progression from point A to point B, swinging from ropes, jumping from burning buildings, etc. The puzzles were challenging enough to keep me interested, and were quite entertaining. This game accomplishes something that many games in the have struggled with in the past, it makes you feel as if you are an explorer, an adventure, it makes you interested in what you will find. If you look at the game and think, "Hey I think I might enjoy that" buy it, play it, love it. 8.9/10 Amazing

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												I can comfortably recommend this game- the first thing to note is that it is, visually, just absolutely stunning, and the voice acting is totally on point.Whilst this game is, by definition, a free roaming game (as you can fast travel around the island to explore) I found that I didn't need to fast travel- not even once- through the entire campaign, and that is because Tomb Raider's true accolades lie with the incredibly strong storyline, which 100% makes up for the fact that the game is really quite linear. Even on the default difficulty, the AI behaves somewhat intelligently- enough to keep you on your toes. If you remain sedentary, they'll flank you, and they will keep you pinned down using bullets, arrows and firebombs. The game also has just enough suspense to hold your attention (as we've grown to expect from Montreal) as well as really fantastic character development- you truly do root for Lara.In terms of FLAWS though, I'd say that this game isn't perfect- if you play strategically and stealthy like I do (meaning you use your bow and axe as much as possible, and always go for the headshots) then you'll find the other weapons to be more like extra accessories, and you'll also find a lot more ammo than you really need. Maybe I played it wrong? Maybe you're meant to spray and pray? Idk...I also found the perk system a bit pointless- there were very few actually decent perks, and they really didn't change the game much. I'd also say that this game is just chock full of quicktime events. Like seriously. And whilst these take a little bit of getting used to, once you progress into the game, they'll become incredibly predictable (but I wouldn't call them tedious) and you'll see them happen long before they actually do.This game is definitely worth playing if you want to experience a really quality game, where you can experience the fruits of all of the hard work that went into creating it. It doesn't take too long to complete, but it really is a worthwhile journey.

												I picked this up not long ago on a daily deal for a mere $5, and how could you say no to having a recent AAA title with graphics such as these for that price?I truly think this game is the best the series has ever offered, and I believe that it will bring a lot of new attention to the genre and the series itself because it has been executed so well. The game actually begs you to complete more and more of it.I would have loved to have seen more survival driven elements but it was balanced to a point of being enjoyable without having too much action. Some of the action is intense and really quite unique to the genre and these are the most enjoyable parts of the game in my eyes.The game has spiked an interest in the reboot for myself and I'll be getting the next one in the series, which has been hinted to take place in Croatia.You should get this game, even if it's just for some weekend action.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2013
												Forget all you know about Lara Croft, the reboot of the Tomb Raider franchise is really an "unchartification" of the series, and I'm so glad it is. The developers managed to make an action-adventure game that's grim, dark, violent but at the same time it offers a good share of exploration, puzzles and beautiful landscapes. It also isn't a clone of said game, while it clearly borrows the hollywood movie action scenes and timed events, it doesn't abuse them and everything fits perfectly. The game also add things that Uncharted lacked, as backtracking and exploration letting you to step out of the "rails" of the main story to complete the optional quests. This said, game's story is interesting and unfolds nicely. Combat feels well, while it's not very complex, it offers the player a nice quantity of alternatives and tactics to adapt it to his gameplay style. Controls work well, aren't awkward at all and visuals are stunning. As for the bad side of the game, there isn't really to much to rant about, Lara's character development was maybe rushed, she also takes an unhuman quantity of physical punishment through the game and boss battles, and combat in general, wasn't very challenging even in the hardest difficulty. 2013 must play, and I'm hoping to see more of Lara's adventures in the future. 8.8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 17, 2015
												Having never played a Tomb Raider game before I felt that this game is a really nice entry point. It has some really good graphics, The gameplay is really nice, and the graphics are excelent. I liked this game a lot. I felt that it was really well done however I felt the story was a bit to short. I got 10 hours of gameplay in and I felt like I took my time. One thing that I feel was done rather well was the progression of your weapons as you play going from a crude wooded bow to a high powered compound bow. I liked the gameplay style as well. It allows for multiple styles of gameplay. You can sneak passed enemies or you can go in guns blazing. I prefer the sneaky style of play and found it to be quite well done. In terms of story I felt it was really well done as well with the character evolving as you play though the game. It is also the one game that I have played where I get a feel for how much the character suffers. The story does suffer from being a bit on the short side for my liking making the game rather quick and to be honest as good as the game is I am not that tempted to go for a replay. Overall I think it is a good game. I can't comment on how well it fits into the Tomb Raider franchise but as a game it has nice graphics, a decent story, and lets just say that Lara's cries in pain are a bit to sensual to be pain.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 17, 2015
												This game is very fun. The graphics are very, very good. The whole atmosphere of the game is a huge clash between Industrialization, old japanese culture and nature which this game presented very well. Forests were lush and detailed down to flowers and branches. Ships that were claimed by storm and lightning each had a different look that matched its time period. Some caves could have been done without so many skulls and dead bodies hanging around, but it added to the eeriness of the island and the mystery it contained.The music was good at setting the mood. It is normally quiet when safe to roam, letting the ambient noise enthrall you into the world. But the soundtrack picks up as action builds which just keeps you going. The drips of water in caves to the whistling of the winds comes together seemlessly.The pacing was just right. You backtrack to certain areas but with new, upgraded weapons allowing you to find new tombs and treasures. You can easily get side tracked, but not to the degree of Skyrim or Fallout where you could spend 10 hours doing something else. The main story grips you and you want to keep moving forward. The up and downs of action to exploration was very smooth and it felt like I had a lot more freedom than actually given. It's a semi-open world with backtracking features via fast travel. It works.The combat was tight and responsive. I wish it was a litle more difficult at times, especially in the 50-75% zones. Each weapon and upgrade was significant. The quiet but deadly Bow is the bread and butter of Lara's arsenals. The handgun can be upgraded to a fast mid-ranged weapon to clear out oncoming baddies. The shotgun is great for blowing off armors and fast close ranged fights while the Rifle was good for piercing through thin walls and picking off Snipers or Archers.There are other, more in-depth reviews out there so I'll keep mine at this length. If you like exploring, third-person action and collecting items/audio logs (that really do flesh out the story A LOT), Tomb Raider is an amazing reboot and you should give it a shot.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 19
												I have never been a fan of the Tomb Raider series, through out my life I have tried different ones but I just never found the appeal, with this game however; all of that changed. As many know by this point, the game is set before lara becomes her tomb raiding self and I think for newbies to the series or people like me that were never fans of the series this is a very good thing as she is just a normal woman and you can see all the things she goes through to become who she does, you do not need any previous knowledge of Tomb Raider to play this game or enjoy it. The story is a good length and at no point for me dragged in any place, I was fully invested in the story from beginning to end and enjoyed watching her charcater arc and was left at the end wanting more, there is more than just the main story of course as there are tombs with puzzles for you to work out, challenges to do, collectibles to find which is enjoyable because when it comes to the artifacts she tells you about them. All of that stuff is completly optional though even the majority of the tombs, so if you do not enjoy that kind of stuff than do not worry you will not be forced through it :) there is also a lot of action in the game to keep you busy and weapon upgrades you can unlock through getting salvage.  The graphics in this game are amazing, my computer was able to play it on the highest settings and even though the game came out years ago it looked a lot better than games coming out these days.If I was in Lara's place I would have been done within the first 20 minutes, but watching her go through all the things she does and watch it shape her it helps you realise what is behind "tomb raider" that she did not just wake up one day and decide to be a badass tomb explorer killing things. I very highly recommend this game and can not wait until I am able to buy the next one.

												Get this game for cheap, like 7$ at most. This game delivers some good looking, tense, action sequences, and the story and gun control are fine.
